name: Introkit
keyboard: 20 keys, 16 Hexadecimal key and 4 command keys
description:
Launched in 1976, the Introkit appeared to be very popular. It was the first affordable all-in-one computer everyone could acquire to know a bit about computers.

The basic version was really minimalist: one SC/MP (or "Scamp") microprocessor, one 512-byte ROM containing a monitor program and 256 bytes of RAM for user's programs.

The system was designed to connect to a Teletype - the CPU had serial In and Out pins, but very few hobbyist could afford this massive and expensive equipment. N.S. thus released an optional display kit which was comprised of an add-on card that fitted onto the main board, and a modified calculator for keyboard and display. The machine also needed a dual voltage PSU

Once everything soldered and wire-wrapped, the Introkit was a complete computer and an efficient learning tool. The novice programmer could enter, modify and run programs and thus learn all hardware and software basic concepts of any computing system.

Several of these kits - and other SC/MP machines, were connected to larger computers thanks to the unique and advanced ability of the SC/MP CPU to completely share its system bus with other processors, and thus run smoothly in a multiprocessor environment.

Chris Curry took the Introkit as a starting point to design the MK-14 training board, first Sinclair computer.

Ben Mullett recalls:
I joined NSC Bedford in '77 when the SC/MP was the latest in micros, my first task was to get an Introkit working, with help from Dave Brown. I can still recall some of the Hex opcodes for this machine.... C4 was LDI or 'Load immediate'... 

The Introkit was indeed a TTY machine, with a modified NSC calculator case and keys forming the (extra cost) KBDkit and a patched ROM to scan the keys.

The Introkit/KBDkit to MK14 development liaison to Science of Cambridge was Tony Amendt, another National Semiconductor Field Applications Engineer.  

He helped me get an MK14 running - allegedly the first kit made - since I was fortunate to be given the task of checking out the kit and  instructions.  All that was missing were some pullup resistors on the bus.  Ran well, but what a weird keyboard!  Very Sinclair.....

The SC/MP LCDS was the official development tool - 'Low Cost Development System' and there was a multiprocessing card demo for it that was quite impressive.  Might even have that in my attic somewhere!  

The multiprocessing architecture reappeared on the Series 32000 (aka NS16000) micros that were used in the Sequent 'Balance' series of Unix machines a decade later.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> INTROKIT</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> 1 MHz quartz oscillator<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> This regulator provides the -7V voltage needed by the CPU, from the -12V<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> SC/MP microprocessor<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> 256 bytes RAM chips (2x2101)<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> 512 bytes ROM chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> TTL chips used for the serial communication<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Display driver chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> Keyboard/display connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> 64-pin connector. In this version, only three power supply pins are connected.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOLDER SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Note the wire-wrapped connections between the keyboard/display interface and the CPU pins.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TELETYPE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Claude Paillard for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TELETYPE DETAIL</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Claude Paillard for this picture</p></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice advert, although a little excessive.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover of a French Commodore-PC brochure.<br><br> 'Hats off to Commodore!'  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMIGA POSTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #5 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said:<br><br> No waiting for software<font color="#666666"> ...This exciting micro has fired the imagination of programmers who are busy developping new software to take full advantage of its performance capabilities...</font><br><br> No wait state<font color="#666666"> ...One advantage is the total elimination of memory access wait states so that interaction between the processor, RAM and disk drive is speeded up...</font><br><br> A free p-System for those who don't wait <font color="#666666"> ...A free p-System operating system and PASCAL, FORTRAN 77 and BASIC compilers which alone lists for $1475, we're now including free with the Sage II...</font>  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computing today to be ready for tomorrow"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SPANISH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">... One of the results is our new identity and our new product: the Intersystems DPS-1. An IEEE S-100 compatible mainframe with features that live up to its look. <i>Dependable</i> operation to 4 Mhz. Twenty-card capacity, a modular power supply. And something no one else has: built-in break points to give you a faster, more powerful tool for testing software as well as hardware...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>TO-7/70 playing AIRBUS, a flight sim...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>This promotional picture was used to emphasize the programming assets of the TO-7/70 : Microsoft Basic v5, Microsoft assembler and SOLI Logo. They want to make us believe that architects used TO-7/70 !  <br><br> As usual there are no cables shown... The arm looks weird, lifeless... did they cut it to take the picture more easily ?! or is the woman completely laid down on the table ?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GENEVA AD, NOV. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD SYSTEMS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

Its is exactly the same advert used for the model 5000, apart some modification in the description (disk drive capacity). Even the picture is still the same, with a "5" added with a pen, by hand !!!</blockquote>
